entry.title: Re: The "Create New Analysis" (READINESSCHECK) button is...
entry.content:
Although SAP Readiness Check continues to support S-user logins, the platform now requires the following two additional authorizations:
â€¢ Display SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to view all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to the customer number associated with their user ID.
â€¢ Manage SAP Readiness Check Analysis: Enables S-users to create, edit, delete, and share all SAP Readiness Check analyses belonging to their customer number.
To request these authorizations, please contact your company's Super Administrator(s) listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me. They have the authority to assign the required authorizations via S-User Management - SAP for Me.  
Alternatively, you can submit a self-service authorization request directly through SAP for Me. Access the request page using this link: https://me.sap.com/preferences/authorizations. You can also navigate to the Profile icon in the top-right corner of the SAP for Me header bar, select "My Settings," go to the "Authorizations and Functions" tab, and choose "Request Authorization."  

For additional details about SAP for Me's self-service authorization capabilities, you can refer to KBA 2891528. Further guidance is available the KBAs 3310759 and 3545701, which address the revised authorization concept and missing button issue in the SAP Readiness Check Dashboard.

entry.title: Re: partner determination ship to party
entry.content:
Why it happens is because, Partner determination procedure (VOPAN) defines which partner functions (Sold-to, Ship-to, Bill-to, Payer) are mandatory or optional for a given sales document type. Each account group (e.g., B001 vs. C001) has its own partner determination procedure assigned in customer master configuration. If the account groupâ€™s partner procedure doesnâ€™t include Ship-to Party (or marks it differently), the system wonâ€™t propose it automatically in the sales order. That is why dealer 13200 (account group B001) behaves differently than dealers in C001.

Steps to resolve

  • Check account group settings in SPRO and verify which partner determination procedure is assigned to B001 vs. C001. Compare them â€” likely C001 has Ship-to Party included, while B001 does not.
  • Go to Partner Determination in VOPAN for Customer Master, ensure Ship-to Party (SH) is included in the procedure assigned to B001. Mark it as mandatory if you want the system to always propose it.
  • Confirm that ZREW uses the correct partner determination procedure. If ZREW is linked to a procedure that expects Ship-to but the customerâ€™s account group doesnâ€™t provide it, youâ€™ll get the error.
  • The customer account groupâ€™s partner procedure and the sales order typeâ€™s partner procedure must align. If they mismatch, the system wonâ€™t propose Ship-to automatically.

In short, the error is not in ZREW itself but in the partner determination procedure assigned to account group B001. Align it with C001 or adjust ZREWâ€™s procedure, and the issue will be resolved.

entry.title: Re: Exposing application service running in Kyma cluster using APIRule
entry.content:
@mbeljic Hello,

Check your host if you are using the wildcard directly in the host like:

hosts:
- fastapi-hello.*.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

then this may caused issue 
you should directly use the name in the host like
hosts:
- fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com


After the above correction check the CPI call as well if the CPI is calling the http request then this will fail (sometimes as DNS error depending on adapter)
http://fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

 

The CPI must use the https request like
https://fastapi-hello.c-123456.kyma.ondemand.com

then there will be no exceptions

 

Hope the above steps resolve your issue...

entry.title: Re: MRP user exit/BAdI to filter BOM components by procur...
entry.content: The cleanest solution is to use BAdI MD_CHANGE_MRP_DATA or EXIT_SAPLM61C_001 to filter BOM components during MRP explosion, allowing only procurement type F items to generate requirements. But please be careful that suppressing E items means no planned orders will be created for them. If those items are needed elsewhere, you must ensure they are covered by other planning runs. Test thoroughly with simulation runs (MD02/MD03) before moving to production. Document the logic clearly, since this is a non-standard planning behavior.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Supplier Management & Risk 2602 Release Key Innovations Preview
entry.content:
Supplier Lifecycle & Performance

Ability to Restrict Hierarchy Level Selection for Department and Region in Questionnaire Configuration (SLP-2309)

With this feature, template creators can now configure hierarchy level selection restrictions for Department and Region question types in the same way they can for Commodity questions. Respondents can select only within specified hierarchy levels, improving accuracy in data selection and reducing manual review and correction efforts. (Learn more.)


Integration Support for Supplier Qualification Status (SLP-2387)

This feature adds support for synchronizing supplier qualification status to integrated ERP systems using custom generic fields. This change allows you to access up-to-date qualification information directly in the ERP system, facilitating automated decision-making processes such as blocking suppliers with expired qualifications. (Learn more.)


Ability to Restrict the Number of Commodity, Region, and Department Answers in Process Intake Forms (SLP-2392)

This feature enables you to configure the maximum number of answers process initiators can add to Commodity, Region, and Department questions in process intake forms. (Learn more.)


Ability to Perform Real-time Validation and Version Comparison for Supplier Questionnaire (SLP-2377)

This feature enables you to validate the data in real-time for supplier responses to external questionnaires. It allows buyers to compare validated current responses with previously approved versions. This enhances data accuracy and compliance with buyer standards. It also accelerates supplier onboarding. (Learn more.)


Additional Project Header Fields for Conditional Approvals (SLP-2386)

This feature increases the number of project header fields available for creating conditional approval workflows beyond the current six fields. This change allows you to create more conditional approval flows per questionnaire. (Learn more.)


Ability to Restrict Hierarchy Level Selection for Department and Region in Modular Questionnaire Configuration (SLP-2408)

With this feature, template creators can configure hierarchy level selection restrictions in the modular questionnaire template for Department and Region question types in the same way they can for Commodity questions . Respondents can select only within specified hierarchy levels, improving accuracy in data selection and reducing manual review and correction efforts. (Learn more.)


Additional AI Copilot Joule Capabilities for Finding Suppliers, Supplier Contacts, and Supplier Management Projects (SLP-2411)

This feature adds capabilities for using AI copilot Joule to find more information about suppliers and supplier management projects, including approval status and pending approvers for projects created by the current user, qualified and preferred suppliers, and suppliers with expiring or expired certificates. It also enhances the scenario for finding supplier contact information. (Learn more.)

 

Supplier Performance Evaluations in SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance (NGSM-2269)

This feature allows buyers to create and manage programs for conducting periodic supplier performance evaluations, which evaluate suppliers for performance based on key indicators determined by your organization. (Learn more.)

 

Supplier Risk

Ability to Enhance Risk Control Effectiveness by Automating Residual Risk Calculation (NGSM-1273)

This feature enables you to automate the effectiveness review of risk controls by using modular questionnaire scoring based on predefined criteria, eliminating the need for manual assessment. (Learn more.)


Ability to Create an Engagement Request from a Supplier Request Data (SRISK-1878)

This feature enables you to create engagement requests directly from approved supplier requests, removing repetitive manual steps and ensuring data consistency between supplier requests and engagement requests. You will receive a pop up message once the engagement request is created. (Learn more.)


Enhancing Supplier Risk Exposure API By Adding New Data Fields in Response (SRISK-1887)

This feature introduces a new version of the Supplier Risk Exposure API. In addition with the exposure details in the response, this new version has additional two fields data in the API response. (Learn more.)

 

Stay connected with your community for more insights and updates:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
  • Whatâ€™s New

entry.title: SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026): Useful Guide of Nextâ€‘Gen GRC
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  • 1. Introduction:
  • 2. Modules of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 3. SAP Roadmap and plan for SAP GRC solutions
  • 4. Release Dates for SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 4.1. Early Adopter Customers
  • 4.2. Regular Customers
  • 5. How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) from SAP GRC v1200?
  • 6. Few New features of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)
  • 6.1. SAP Access Control
  • 6.2. SAP Process Control
  • 6.3. SAP Risk Management
  • 6.4. SAP Audit Management
  • 6.5. SAP Business Integrity Screening
  • 6.6. SAP Tax Compliance
  • 6.7. SAP UIDP Masking
  • 6.8. SAP UIDP Logging
  • 7. Key characteristics
  • 8. Licensing model
  • 9. Benefits
  • 10.Conclusion

 

1.     Introduction:

SAP is entering a major transformation phase in Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC). With the introduction of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026), SAP is consolidating and modernizing its entire GRC portfolio to support S/4HANA, cloud adoption, realâ€‘time analytics, and continuous compliance.

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 has quickly become one of the most discussed topics among organizations, leaders, IT directors, managers, SMEs, consultants, and vendors working in SAP Security and GRC. This 2026 release is designed for both onâ€‘premise and private cloud deployments. It is ideal for organizations that want to remain onâ€‘premise or private cloud while maintaining longâ€‘term GRC capabilities, especially those using or planning to use modules such as SAP Process Control or SAP Risk Management.

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is SAPâ€™s nextâ€‘generation unified GRC platform, built natively on SAP HANA.

 

2.     Modules of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

Within SAPâ€™s GRC portfolio, there are multiple solutions that cover both onâ€‘premise and cloudâ€‘based offerings.

 To learn more about the onâ€‘premise SAP GRC solutions, you may refer to the blog  Kickstart your SAP GRC Learning Journey: Introduction to SAP GRC, Submodules and useful links

 To learn more about the cloud SAP GRC solutions, you may refer to the blog  Kickstart your Cloud SAP GRC Learning Journey: Introduction to Cloud SAP GRC, its Submodules details

 SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is delivered as a single unified software component that includes all 8 of the following modules:

  • SAP Access Control
  • SAP Process Control
  • SAP Risk Management
  • SAP Audit Management
  • SAP Tax Compliance
  • SAP Business Integrity Screening
  • SAP UI Data Protection Masking
  • SAP UI Data Protection Logging

Image source: SAP

3.     SAP Roadmap and plan for SAP GRC solutions

See below SAP Road map of existing SAP GRC v1200 and new SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 along with modules it it.

Image source: SAP

You may refer to the Details for Product Version SAP GRC FOR SAP HANA 1.0

 

4.     Release Dates for SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

4.1.           Early Adopter Customers

If you have already registered as a Early Adopters, SAP planned to release in March 2026.

4.2.           Regular Customers

For General/regular availability it will be early Q3-2026

5.     How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) from SAP GRC v1200?

Organizations can choose the â€œHub Modelâ€ or â€œEmbedded Modelâ€ for their SAP GRC for HANA (SAP GRC 2026) upgrade/migration.  In case if an existing Hub Model setup customer wants to move to Embedded model, it is like a new implementation of SAP GRC for HANA 2026 but can reuse existing GRC design.

To migrate from SAP GRCv1200 to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026), this requires below 2 prerequisites

  1. SAP NetWeaver should be minimum SAP S/4HANA Foundation (it is just an upgraded version for SAP NetWeaver). This is not SAP S/4HANA full version. Organizations who are using SAP Fiori 2.0 would have already migrated their SAP NetWeaver to SAP S/4HANA Foundation. Incase if you are having lower version of GRC Support pack or still on Fiori 1.0 or using SAP NetWeaver as a base component for SAP GRC, then this is a mandatory step.  In case for an Embedded GRC model, SAP GRC for HANA 2026 can be installed on S4Core.
  2. Databased as HANA DB: SAP GRC for HANA1.0 only supports SAP HANA DB, Organizations are forced to migrate their Non-HANA Database to HANA DB.

Once the above prerequisites are complete, SAP GRC v12.0 can be upgraded to SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 release as part of their standard maintenance program, meaning no new SKU or additional purchase is required.

 

6.     Few New features of SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026)

6.1.           SAP Access Control

  • Augmented Access request process
  • AI supported User Access Review process
  • AI driven Emergency Access Management log review process for monitoring, identifying and responding to potential security threats
  • Fiori based Access Request and approver process
  • Compliance reporting with extended analytics
  • Out of the box Fiori based reports â€“ OVP
  • Additional Data source â€“ Integrating Identity Services IdDs
  • SuccessFactors â€“ Expand rulesets to include target populations
  • New EAM logs for Read Access Logs (RAL)
  • New Fiori App for Approval Work inbox

6.2.           SAP Process Control

  • SAP Joule integration to create Data Source and Business rules, also to understand the table and required logic.
  • Issue Analytics: Smartness for issue analysis and resolution
  • MSMP is extended to PC workflows
  • No new enhancements for Policy Management
  • Improved User Experience: Utilizing Fiori Apps for enhanced usability and accessibility (My Compliance Tasks, MCP, Assessments, Intelligent Self Diagnostic)
  • Single Entry Control Screen: Streamlining operation (Manage Controls)
  • Intelligent Self-Diagnostic Cockpit: Error analysis and resolution capabilities (CCM)
  • Enhanced Integration: Leveraging the SAP Integration Suite and Framework for seamless connectivity
  • Flexible Workflow Management: Adapting to business needs with customizable workflows
  • Regulatory Alignment: Integrating with Regulatory Insights for compliance and oversight

6.3.           SAP Risk Management

  • Harmonized Email Notification â€“ Planner/Scheduler enhancement
  • Business Continuity Management
  • MSMP is extended to RM workflows
  • SAP Joule integration to create KRIs, also to understand the tables/CDS views etc.

6.4.           SAP Audit Management

  • Overview page for Audit Coverage
  • Import Master Data from PC/RM in same system per the push of a button
  • Inspection Management module
  • Consolidate email notifications for multiple actions
  • AI Supported Audit Report Generation
  • AI Supported work program preparation

6.5.           SAP Business Integrity Screening

  • Fiori apps for Detection Runs
  • Improving performance for Managing Alerts App

6.6.           SAP Tax Compliance

  • Bulk Edit User group attributes

6.7.           SAP UIDP Masking

  • Extending UI Masking to ODATA V4 applications and BW/4AHNA scenarios
  • Configurations need to be done in Central S/4 or S/4Foundation system
  • No need to install it in each connected system.

6.8.           SAP UIDP Logging

  • Streamlined UI lugging optimized for SAP HANA
  • Configurations need to be done in Central S/4 or S/4Foundation system
  • No need to install it in each connected system.

7.     Key characteristics

  • Built on SAP HANA
  • HANA DB is mandatory
  • Fioriâ€‘based user experience
  • Realâ€‘time analytics
  • Cloudâ€‘ready architecture
  • Integration with SAP Joule, BTP, SAP IAG, SAP Cloud Identity Services

8.     Licensing model

Licence is still separate for each GRC module; hence customers need to buy a separate licence based on required module.

9.     Benefits

  • Unified GRC platform
  • AI Integration
  • Easier deployment
  • Reduced complexity
  • Reduce TOC with increased ROI
  • Modern Fiori UX
  • Improved Reporting
  • Futureâ€‘proof roadmap

10.Conclusion

SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 (SAP GRC 2026) is more than an upgrade â€” it is a complete modernization of SAPâ€™s GRC landscape. It brings realâ€‘time capabilities, unified architecture, cloud readiness, and a simplified user experience.

For organizations, leaders, IT directors, managers, SMEs, consultants, and vendors, now is the time to:
- Understand the new platform
- Assess your current GRC landscape
- Plan your migration strategy
- Align with SAPâ€™s longâ€‘term roadmap

The future of GRC is realâ€‘time, automated, cloudâ€‘ready, and unified â€” and SAP GRC for HANA 1.0 is the platform that delivers it.

#SAP GRC #SAP GRC 2026  #SAP GRC for HANA 1.0

entry.title: Integrate GitHub with SAP Cloud Integration using Open Connectors: Fetch & Decode File Content
entry.content:
Integrating our systems with third-party platforms like GitHub has become a common requirement in todayâ€™s business landscape, especially when working with public repositories that store documentation and configuration files.

In this blog post, Iâ€™ll walk you through how to connect SAP Open Connectors for GitHub with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to fetch a file from a GitHub repository and decode its contents. Weâ€™ll use SAP Open Connectors to securely access GitHub resources and apply a Groovy script in CPI to decode the Base64-encoded file content, helping you build a simple and reliable end-to-end integration.

By the end of this blog, youâ€™ll have a clear understanding of how to:

1. Set up a GitHub instance in SAP Open Connectors

2.Connect SAP Open Connectors with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)

Step 1: Fetching and decoding file content using Groovy scripting

To begin, you first need to create a GitHub instance in SAP Open Connectors. Start by logging in to the SAP BTP Cockpit and navigating to the SAP Open Connectors dashboard. This is where youâ€™ll configure and manage your GitHub connection before using it in SAP Cloud Integration.

 

To get started, select the GitHub connector from the list of available connectors in SAP Open Connectors.

 

Next, enter your GitHub details. Provide your GitHub account name and the repository name. Make sure the repository you choose is public, as this is required for access without additional authentication

Once the details are filled in, click Create Instance. This will open the configuration screen where you can complete the setup for your GitHub instance.

 

Step 2: Testing GitHub APIs using Interactive API Docs

Before connecting everything to SAP Cloud Integration, itâ€™s a good practice to test the GitHub connector using the Interactive API Docs provided by SAP Open Connectors. This helps confirm that your GitHub instance is correctly configured and able to retrieve data from your repository.

To do this, open the GitHub instance you just created from the SAP Open Connectors dashboard and navigate to the Interactive API Docs section.

Here, youâ€™ll need to provide the required parameter, such as the file path within the repository (for example, /notes.md). After submitting the request, youâ€™ll receive a JSON response.

After submitting the request, youâ€™ll receive a JSON response. One of the key fields in this response is the content field, which contains the file data encoded in Base64 format.

This confirms that your GitHub instance is set up correctly and is able to access files from the specified public repository. In the next steps, this Base64-encoded content will be decoded in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using a Groovy script.

 

Step 3: Storing Open Connectors Credentials in Security Material

Before using SAP Open Connectors in your iFlow, you need to store the required credentials in SAP Integration Suite.

 

Step 4: Connecting SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) to GitHub using Open Connectors

Once your GitHub instance is set up and running, the next step is to connect it with SAP Cloud Integration so you can retrieve file content from the repository.

To do this, start by creating a new iFlow in your CPI workspace. Add a Sender step, such as a Timer or HTTPS adapter, based on how you want to trigger the flow. Then, add a Receiver step.

For the Receiver, choose the Open Connectors adapter from the list of available adapters. This adapter will be used to connect CPI with GitHub through SAP Open Connectors.

 

Deploy the iFlow and trigger it to run. This will call the GitHub API and fetch the file content, which is returned in a Base64-encoded format.

Once the file content is successfully retrieved from GitHub, youâ€™ll see a response similar to the one shown below.

 

Step 5: Fetching and decoding the file content

At this stage, the file content fetched from GitHub is still in Base64 format, which isnâ€™t readable. To convert it into plain text, you can use a Groovy Script step in your iFlow.

Add a Script step and use the following Groovy code to decode the content:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import java.util.Base64

def Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    def json = new groovy.json.JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    def encodedContent = json.content
    def decodedBytes = Base64.decoder.decode(encodedContent)
    def plainText = new String(decodedBytes, "UTF-8")
    message.setBody(plainText)
    return message
}

 

This script reads the Base64-encoded content from the API response, decodes it, and replaces the message body with the decoded, human-readable text.

After the Groovy script runs successfully, the file content appears as plain text, making it easy to read and use in further processing steps.

Conclusion :

In this blog, we explored how to connect to a public GitHub repository, retrieve file content, and decode it using Groovy scripting in CPI. In the next blog, weâ€™ll take this a step further and look at how to work with private repositories using authentication tokens.

If you have any questions or would like a downloadable iFlow sample, feel free to drop a comment.

entry.title: Re: UB stock transport order miss conditioln tab
entry.content:
Why you donâ€™t see PI01 in Public Cloud STOs is because of the scope limitation. The â€œPricing in Stock Transport Ordersâ€ scope item (available in S/4HANA PCE / On-Premise) is not part of the Public Cloud standard scope. In Public Cloud, STOs are simplified: they handle material movement and delivery scheduling, but not intercompany pricing conditions.

If you need PI01 (intercompany price) in STOs, you must activate the scope item 2EJ â€“ Intercompany Stock Transfer with Delivery or 2EL â€“ Intercompany Stock Transfer with Billing. These scope items enable pricing and billing integration for STOs. Verify if 2EJ (Intercompany STO with Delivery) or 2EL (Intercompany STO with Billing) are activated. Without these, STOs will not have condition tabs.

If you only need valuation for internal transfers (not intercompany billing), use valuation price determination in material master / accounting view. If you need commercial pricing (PI01), you must use intercompany STO scope items.

This SAP CodeJam event is on the topic of the ABAP Cloud, and specifically introduces attendees to ABAP Cloud and the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model. ABAP Cloud is the ABAP-based development model for S/4HANA Cloud, S/4HANA on-premise, and SAP BTP, ABAP environment.

Learn how to use proven and new technologies, such as Core Data Services (CDS) and behavior definition and implementation languages, to build SAP Fiori apps and OData services on any of the ABAP Cloud options. In this hands-on experience, developers will create their first ABAP applications using ABAP Cloud, expose and consume services via HTTP, and explore the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model.

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Wednesday, 18th February 2026 in Auckland, New Zealand from 09:00 - 15:30 (NZDT). The language and content of the event will be in English.

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2601 â€“ Whatâ€™s New?
entry.content:
Welcome to the latest SAP Community update, where we bring you the newest enhancements across SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace. This release equips shippers, carriers, and solution owners with deeper visibility, smarter automation, and more flexible integration optionsâ€”covering everything from container-level tracking to improved event governance.

 

Cross SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration and Global Track and Trace

Supporting container type in shipment tracking

Container information is now supported in both the â€˜Consumer API for Order Tracking (GTT)â€™ and the â€˜Consumer API for Order Tracking (FC)â€™. A container object has been added with the parameters â€˜containerNoâ€™ and â€˜containerTypeâ€™. This information is used to calculate container demurrage.

For supported container type codes, please refer to Container Types.

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Caching enabled to improve performance

Performance has been improved in the â€˜Manage Invoicesâ€™ app through the introduction of caching for â€˜General Settingsâ€™. This optimization reduces repeated calls and accelerates processing for large batches of invoices. Please note that changes made in the â€˜General Settingsâ€™ app under â€˜Define Appointment and Dispute Settingsâ€™ can take up to 15 minutes to be reflected in the carrierâ€™s 'Manage Invoices' app.

Contracting: Share and view additional address details

The â€˜Consumer API for Freight Subcontractingâ€™ now supports sharing of additional address details such as lot numbers and site locations. In the â€˜Freight Orders for Confirmationâ€™ app, these details are displayed for carriers within the departure and arrival address fields in the worklist, and in the â€˜Informationâ€™ and â€˜Tourâ€™ tabs of the freight order detail view.

 

 

 By capturing more granular location information, shippers and carriers can deliver to specific locations within larger sites, which increases delivery accuracy and improves logistics efficiency.

Contracting: Filter freight orders by document category â€˜consignmentâ€™

Consignment orders are now easier to identify in the worklist through the new â€˜document categoryâ€™ filter. This help carriers avoid data inconsistencies and streamline processing for consignment scenarios.

 

 In the 'Freight Order Details' page, the â€˜Drivers and Resource Detailsâ€™ tab is not available for consignment orders.

In addition, driver and resource information must not be provided for consignment orders using the Provider API for Freight Subcontracting. Specifically, the fields driver1Name, driver2Name, trailerID, and truckID are not supported and will trigger an error if submitted.

LBN ID now displayed in the carrier drop down when assigning tolerance group

To aid configuration accuracy, the 'General Settings' app now displays the carrierâ€™s LBN ID alongside the business partner name in the carrier dropdown under 'Assign Tolerance Group'. This addition helps shippers and administrators distinguish between partners that share the same or similar names.

 Updates to EDI 214 and IFTMIN

Documentation has been updated to enhance integration reliability. The Message Implementation Guideline for ANSI X12 214 FC now correctly maps the AG status code to the EVENT_EST_UPD event type, ensuring accurate representation of shipment status events. For EDIFACT, the IFTMIN D96A guideline has been expanded to include vendorId and totalChargesAmount in the mapping logic, enabling richer data exchange for carriers.

 

SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace

Fulfillment rate calculation logic enhanced to support batch split scenarios

The calculation logic for sales order fulfillment rates and On-Time In-Full (OTIF) status has been enhanced to accurately handle scenarios where outbound delivery items are split into different batches for shipping.

The sample code extractor has been updated accordingly, and users must download the latest version from our GitHub repository to take advantage of these improvements.

Event reporting now supports URL attachments

Carriers or visibility providers can add a private URL as an attachment when reporting events via the â€˜Provider API for Order Events (GTT)â€™ or the Write Service API. The APIs now include the parameter â€˜privateAttachementURLâ€™, which stores an access-restricted link that can be displayed with the event in the tracking timeline.

In the â€˜Track Shipmentsâ€™ app, solution owners can view these attachments in the event table and  add a URL by themselves.

 

 

 These URLs can be synchronized back to Transportation Management embedded in SAP S/4HANA.

Please note that actual events with URL attachments cannot be sent to the â€˜Manage Freight Executionâ€™ app.

Documentation update on sending documents

The guide â€œHow to Send Documents from SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace to Other Systemsâ€ has been expanded with two new topics: adding new event types for synchronizing back to Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA, and stopping actual events from synchronizing back to Transportation Management in SAP S/4HANA. These additions give solution owners greater control over event governance and system behavior.

We encourage teams working with APIs and tracking applications to review these enhancements and update their integrations where necessary.

 

--------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2601. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2601 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: Cannot change Revenue Recognition Key to SPFCSC for C...
entry.content:
I would also like to add this information.

Status "In progress", on the project, does not block additional posting on the WBS elements (e.g. cost posting as time allocations ) - which can have influence on PoC and revenue.
Status "completed" block additional  cost and billing posting - there is only possible EBRR posting through EBRR revenue recognition period end closing run - to finalize revenue.

Additional performance view:
Projects with status "in process" and "Completed" are always included to "EBRR period end closing run" and EBRR is still trying to check all posting and revenue balances.
Status "Closed" on project will exclude projects from further EBRR processing.

It is recommanded to close your projects at the end of life cycle to achieve better performance for EBRR period end closing runs.

entry.title: Re: How Does HRIS Sync Handle Time Zones and Effective Da...
entry.content:
Hi hyeongeun_lee,

There are two types of HRIS synchronization. The first is the scheduled sync that you mentioned, and the second is the â€œreal-timeâ€ sync.

The real-time sync occurs when data is updated through the UI. In this case, the synchronization process is triggered automatically as soon as you save changes to the record. For example, if an employee is terminated in the UI effective today in the morning (KST), it would still be the afternoon of the previous day in Mexico.

These cases cannot be prevented because they do not rely on the scheduled HRIS sync, as explained, but the real-time sync.

For more details on how these two types of HRIS sync work, please refer to this KBA - 2080728 - Employee Central: What is HRIS Sync? .

Thank you.

Best Regards,

Karen Perez

entry.title: When NOT to Write ABAP: Architectural Decisions
entry.content:
Most of us started our ABAP journey with a simple belief: â€œIf thereâ€™s a requirement, ABAP can solve it.â€ And honestly â€” that belief made sense. ABAP has always been powerful, flexible, and reliable.

But somewhere between ECC â†’ S/4HANA â†’ Cloud â†’ Clean Core, the rules quietly changed.

Today, writing ABAP is no longer just about solving a requirement. Itâ€™s about deciding whether you are creating a solution or future pain.

This is about those moments where writing ABAP feels right, but architecturally, itâ€™s the wrong decision.

 

Why This Question Even Matters Today?

In the ECC days, writing custom code felt normal. Enhancements were everywhere, and upgrades were painful regardless, so no one really questioned it. Today, things are different. Systems upgrade often, cloud readiness matters, and Clean Core isnâ€™t a choice anymore. Every unnecessary Z program now makes upgrades harder, reduces flexibility, and creates long-term maintenance pain. The real danger isnâ€™t writing ABAPâ€”itâ€™s writing ABAP that never needed to be written.

 

Donâ€™t Write ABAP Just Because You Can

This is a common trap. A requirement comes in, and the instinct is to build a Z solution. But often, standard SAP, configuration or CDS already solve it. Weâ€™ve all seen custom reports, workflows, and validations built over existing standard features. The problem isnâ€™t skillâ€”itâ€™s skipping the pause.

An architect first asks: â€œwhat already exists?â€

 

Donâ€™t Write ABAP for Simple Read-Only Reporting

Letâ€™s be honestâ€”much of custom ABAP is still written just to read data, join tables, and display results. In the past, ABAP reports were the only option. Today, they usually arenâ€™t. If a program only reads data, applies minimal logic, and exists mainly for consumption, ABAP is probably the wrong choice. CDS views, embedded analytics, OData services, or standard APIs often do the job better.

 A simple rule helps here: if your logic is mostly SELECT, try modeling before coding.

 

Donâ€™t Write ABAP When Configuration Is the Right Answer

ABAP is often written because:

  • Configuration looks complex
  • Coding feels faster
  • The team is more technical than functional

What often gets missed is that configuration exists to protect the core. It is SAP-supported, upgrade-safe, and far easier for the business to understand and adapt over time. Custom code may solve todayâ€™s requirement, but it struggles to survive change.

I eventually learnt this lesson the hard way: â€œcode fixes the present, configuration secures the future.â€

 

Donâ€™t Write ABAP That Breaks Clean Core Principles

If your ABAP accesses unreleased objects, modifies standard SAP, or depends on obsolete frameworks, it may work todayâ€”but it quietly creates upgrade risk. These shortcuts tie your solution to the current system version and make every future upgrade harder, slower, and more expensive than it needs to be.

A simple question helps:

        â€œWill this survive the next upgrade without rework?â€

If youâ€™re unsure â€” thatâ€™s already your answer.

 

Closing Thought

Good ABAP solves todayâ€™s problem. Good architecture ensures you wonâ€™t have to solve the same problem again tomorrow.
Learning when not to write ABAP has been just as important for me as learning how to write it well especially in today's S/4 HANA and Clean Code World.

entry.title: Re: App - Result Recording for inspection point
entry.content:
Hi,

even though this post is quite old, I'd like to give my comment on it. We had the same problem when we started using this app at one of my customers. We are using a S/4HANA on-premise 2023 FPS02.

In this system environment, there is an important restriction on the Inspection Point Field combination you are assigning in Routing header (also mentioned in SAP Help for this app): only fields "Date" and "Time" are allowed here. We wanted to use two extra attributes, two text fields, which SAP allows to define them in Customizing activity "Define Inspection Points". We defined a new field combination accordingly and assigned this to our routing. But we were not seeing the inpection lots in the app then. They just were not shown, no error messages or so. 

After we changed the Inspection Point Field Combination in the routing (we returned to standard entry 101 "Time based") and created an inspection lot for the production order, the app showed this inspection lot and we could create inspection points to record results.

SAP Help for Public Cloud does not show this restriction, so there it seems to work. I hope that private cloud / on premise installations will also get this possibility in the near future.

So maybe the described issue applies to the creator of this post as well? As I said, probably (hopefully!) solved by now in the meantime, but maybe this answer helps others in their research when they encounter the same problem.

entry.title: Outbound Delivery Cannot Be Recreated After PGI Reversal in SAP S4HANA Cloud EWM
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

In our system, there is a Sales Order for which an Outbound Delivery (OD) was successfully created via VL01N and assigned to an EWM-managed warehouse.

I processed the warehouse execution steps as follows:
Create Warehouse Task â†’ Confirm â†’ Post Goods Issue (PGI).

After that, I needed to change some information on the Sales Order, so I attempted to reverse the Outbound Delivery by performing these actions:

  • Reverse Post Goods Issue

  • Release Stock

  • Adjust the delivery quantity to 0 on the existing Outbound Delivery

However, when I tried to create a new Outbound Delivery again for the same original Sales Order, the system reports that there is no remaining quantity available for delivery.

entry.title: Everything you need to know about "SAP Business Suite"
entry.content:
What are the broad Business Processes?

  • Procurement
  • Production
  • HR
  • Finance
  • Controlling
  • Sales
  • Services

Challenges they face/ their SuccessFactors:

While all business processes face the challenge of enabling stakeholders and end-users to integrate AI into their daily transactions, which will help them driving efficiency, improving decision-making, and unlocking valuable insights, here are some of the precise challenges they will face in their areas, which are their key SuccessFactors:

Procurement:

  • Strategic sourcing and successful stakeholder management
  • Reliable and sustainable suppliers
  • Process efficiency

Production

  • Availability of materials and resources
  • Efficient production processes
  • Actual production costs close to planned costs

HR

  • Strategic alignment and workforce planning
  • Attraction and retention of talents
  • Successful performance management

Finance

  • Precise insights in financial transactions in time
  • Credit-worthiness and payment behavior of business partners
  • Compliance and risk management

Controlling

  • Effective planning and budgeting
  • Accurate and timely data
  • Adequate control systems

Sales

  • Effective integration with the supply chain
  • Customer satisfaction
  • Generating revenue and maintaining profitability

Services

  • Fast reaction times and availability of skilled spare parts within 24 hours
  • Effective planning of service costs and scheduling
  • Use Internet of Things (IoT) for premium bikes

SAP Solutions for Business Process Management

The diagram below offers a comprehensive summary of the main business modules (or processes), their SAP process names, the relevant line of business applications, and the complementary SAP cloud ERP solutions. It clearly maps how Finance, HR, Sales, Services, Production, and Procurement are organized and managed within the SAP ecosystem, linking core business needs directly to SAPâ€™s modular application stack.

 

While we are at it, let's talk briefly about SAP Business Suite:

What is SAP Business Suite?

The name Business Suite actually dates back to on-premise times. Under this label, SAP used to combine a software bundle consisting of SAP ECC (SAP ERP Central Component), SAP CRM (Customer Relationship Management), SAP SRM (Supplier Relationship Management), SAP SCM (Supply Chain Management) and SAP PLM (Product Lifecycle Management).

SAP Business Suite is a modern tool that helps companies manage everything in one place. It uses AI and real-time data to make smarter decisions. Delivered as cloud-based software (SaaS), it brings together AI, data, and business applications so companies can work more efficiently and stay connected.

 

How you can adopt?

Customers can choose two ways to start using SAP Business Suite, depending on what they need.

  • If they already use SAP systems in their own buildings (on-premises), they can switch to the new SAP Business Suite using RISE with SAP, which provides helpful tools and support.
  • If theyâ€™re new to SAP, they can use GROW with SAP to quickly set up and start using SAP Business Suite. This way is fast and easy to scale as their business grows.

 A quick detour on

What is, "RISE with SAP", and what is, "GROW with SAP"?

RISE with SAP

  • Designed for existing SAP customers moving from on-premises systems to a new cloud-based SAP Business Suite.
  • Delivers special tools, expert guidance, and step-by-step support for migration.
  • Best suited for:
    • Clients wanting to preserve current SAP investments while transitioning to the cloud (private cloud focus).
    • Large or upper-mid-market companies with complex processes needing full ERP capabilities.
    • Regulated industries that require private cloud environments.

GROW with SAP

  • Created for new SAP customers starting fresh with SAP Business Suite in the cloud.
  • Enables quick setup using SAP best practices, with scalable and flexible options.
  • Best suited for:
    • New implementations (Greenfield projects) with a public cloud focus.
    • Small and mid-sized enterprises (SMEs) needing rapid, standardized deployment with specialized add-ons.
    • Clients seeking lower total cost of ownership (TCO) and minimal customization.

In summary

  • RISE with SAP is for existing SAP customers who want to move their complex, on-premises systems to a private cloud, with expert support and tools, which is ideal for large companies and regulated industries.
  • GROW with SAP is for new SAP customers or SMEs wanting a fast, standardized set-up in the public cloud, with simple deployment and industry best practices.

Now, going back to our Business Process, which shows  end-to-end processes Lead to Cash, Source to Pay, Design to Operate, Recruit to Retire and their main integration points.

entry.title: Re: issue with SAVE_TEXT Function Module PRLTEXTKZ is not...
entry.content:
Hi,

thank you for the details provided, please find a summary below for the topic.

1.) BAPI BAPI_INSPOPER_RECORDRESULTS is not meant for maintaining long texts. It can store a short text of 40 characters in field REMARK, see corresponding BAPI tables CHAR_RESULTS, SAMPLE_RESULTS, SINGLE_RESULTS.
2.) The long text for QM objects is stored in tables STXH and STXL, but there is always an indicator in the QM application tables which indicates that a long text exists.
This needs to be taken into account when processing long text in any custom way. Such indicators:
QAMR-PRLTEXTKZ
QAMV-LTEXTKZ
QPMT-LTEXTKZ
and so on.

For example, calling the module SAVE_TEXT might store the text in the STXH and STXL tables, but it does not take into account the application tables, as SAVE_TEXT is a general (not application specific) module.
3.) The include LQEEMF3B demonstrates a standard logic for long text processing in QM. It can help when developing some custom code.

Please review and adjust the custom logic accordingly.

Have a nice day,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: QM01 + workflow email subject issue.
entry.content:
Hi Vallamuthu,

I have seen this exact behavior before. It happens because the Work Item Text is language-dependent.

Right now, your system likely only has &EV_SUBJECT& maintained for the English language key. When a user logs in with another language, the system finds that field empty and defaults back to the static Task Name/Abbreviation.

The Fix:

  1. Open your Standard Task in transaction PFTC (Change mode).
  2. Go to the top menu Goto -> Translation.
  3. Select the required languages.
  4. Copy &EV_SUBJECT& into the Work Item Text field for those languages.

Once the variable is there for the other languages, the dynamic subject will appear correctly.

Good luck,

entry.title: ADS error during PDF/A (ZUGFeRD 1.0) conversion â€“ Fonts aren't available:-
entry.content:
Hello experts,
we are currently facing an issue while converting PDFs to ZUGFeRD 1.0 (PDF/A-3B) in an SAP S/4HANA system for E-Invoice.

Scenario

  • Conversion is triggered via method RUN_CONVERT_ZF_1P0 of class CL_FP_CONV_PDFA

  • The conversion fails at runtime in Adobe Document Services (ADS)

ADS Error Message

During execution, ADS throws the following error:

 

#2.0#2026 01 21 16:38:16:143#+0100#Error#com.adobe.ads.request.ADSRequest#
#BC-SRV-FP#com.adobe~DocumentServicesConfiguration#C000AC10030F02150000000800000B24#33747450000000005#com.adobe/AdobeDocumentServices#com.adobe.ads.request.ADSRequest#jms_service#383#JTA Transaction : 9438#262A80EEF6DF11F0CB3500000202F1FA#262a80eef6df11f0cb3500000202f1fa##0#Thread[HTTP Worker [@1326219375],5,Dedicated_Application_Thread]#Plain##
Processing exception during a "ConvertToPdfa" operation.
Request start time: Wed Jan 21 16:38:15 CET 2026
com.adobe.ProcessingException: com.adobe.ProcessingException: com.adobe.ProcessingException: Validation of PDFA output generated failed because its not satisfying compliance test for 3b: Fonts aren't available:- [LANSCO+Helvetica-Bold, YBMUOB+Helvetica, XILUMD+MyriadPro-Regular]

Exception Stack Trace:
com.adobe.ProcessingException: com.adobe.ProcessingException: com.adobe.ProcessingException: Validation of PDFA output generated failed because its not satisfying compliance test for 3b: Fonts aren't available:- [LANSCO+Helvetica-Bold, YBMUOB+Helvetica, XILUMD+MyriadPro-Regular]
	at com.adobe.ads.request.ADSRequest.processOperations(ADSRequest.java:593)
	at com.adobe.ads.request.ADSRequest.process(ADSRequest.java:218)
	at com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.processRequest(AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.java:290)
	at com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.rpData(AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.java:195)
	at com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.rpData(AdobeDocumentServicesEJB.java:179)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)

 

Also in the defaultTrace Log I find following error:

#2.0#2026 01 21 16:38:16:043#+0100#Error#com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServices#
#BC-SRV-FP#com.adobe~DocumentServicesConfiguration#C000AC10030F02150000000300000B24#33747450000000005#com.adobe/AdobeDocumentServices#com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServices#jms_service#383#JTA Transaction : 9438#262A80EEF6DF11F0CB3500000202F1FA#262a80eef6df11f0cb3500000202f1fa##0#Thread[HTTP Worker [@1326219375],5,Dedicated_Application_Thread]#Plain##
Unfixable issue(s)-  Resource Hierarchy: Page: 1 Font (/Type0): ,XILUMD+MyriadPro-Regular C2_0Description: There is some problem with PDF document.,#

#2.0#2026 01 21 16:38:16:138#+0100#Error#com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServices#
#BC-SRV-FP#com.adobe~DocumentServicesConfiguration#C000AC10030F02150000000500000B24#33747450000000005#com.adobe/AdobeDocumentServices#com.adobe.AdobeDocumentServices#jms_service#383#JTA Transaction : 9438#262A80EEF6DF11F0CB3500000202F1FA#262a80eef6df11f0cb3500000202f1fa##0#Thread[HTTP Worker [@1326219375],5,Dedicated_Application_Thread]#Plain##
Unfixable issue(s)- Description: PDF/A entry missing.,PDF/A entry missing.,#

 

Actions Taken

Based on SAP Note 2863090, I performed the following steps:

  1. Uploaded the required font files to

     
    /usr/sap/<SID>/SYS/global/AdobeDocumentServices/FontManagerService

  2. Assigned ownership and permissions to <sid>adm

  3. Restarted:

    • ADS services

    • SAP system

    • Entire host (OS reboot)

After the restart, the file AdobeFnt16.lst.<HOSTNAME> was generated correctly and contains the mentioned fonts.

Additionally, I copied the missing fonts to:

/usr/sap/<sid>adm/J03/j2ee/os_libs/adssap/FontManagerService/fonts/adobe/

Open Questions

  • Why does ADS require Helvetica and MyriadPro-Regular although:

    • These fonts are not used in any Adobe Form (SFP)

    • Only Arial is defined and used in the form layout

  • Is ADS implicitly substituting or embedding fonts during PDF/A-3B conversion?

  • Are there additional ADS or PDF/A configuration steps required for ZUGFeRD 1.0?

Any hints or explanations would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Reconcile Stock in LGM: Bring Transparency to Logistics Stock Differences
entry.content:
Maintaining accurate inventory data across multiple systems is a critical challenge for logistics operations. Today, we're excited to introduce Stock Reconciliation, a new application in SAP Logistics Management (LGM) that ensures your inventory levels stay perfectly aligned between LGM and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

The Challenge

When running warehouse operations in LGM while managing inventory in S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, discrepancies can occur. Integration tasks may fail, system updates might not sync properly, or data migrations can introduce inconsistencies. These gaps create significant problems for financial reporting and operational planning.

How Stock Reconciliation Works

Our brand new app "Reconcile Stock" provides business process specialists with a powerful tool to identify and correct inventory discrepancies. Here's what makes it special:

Comprehensive Visibility

The app compares stock quantities between LGM and S/4HANA side-by-side, showing you exactly where differences exist. You can see the total quantity in each system and the variance at a glance, making it easy to spot discrepancies that need attention.

 

Flexible Filtering

Search and filter stock by warehouse, product,  stock type, plant, and storage location. View all stock lines or focus only on items with differences. The intuitive interface helps you quickly identify what needs attention.

One-Click Corrections

Once you've identified discrepancies, correct them directly to S/4HANA with proper audit logs. The app creates inventory documents and material documents in S/4HANA , ensuring every adjustment is fully trackable and compliant.

 

Understanding Reconciliation Issues

While Stock Reconciliation compares inventory levels between LGM and S/4HANA, sometimes the systems cannot be reconciled due to fundamental data mismatches. Our app provides complete transparency when these issues occur, helping you quickly identify and resolve the root causes.

 

Who and When to Use It

The new app "Reconcile Stock" is designed to be used by the persona of Business Process Specialist at the below critical moments in your operations:

  • After system integrations, migrations, or upgrades
  • During financial period closures (monthly, quarterly, annually)
  • When investigating unexplained inventory discrepancies
  • For regular checks on high-turnover products

Outlook: Intelligent Difference Analysis

We're continuously enhancing Stock Reconciliation to provide even deeper insights into inventory discrepancies. We plan to distinguish between Total Difference and Actual Difference by analyzing failed integration tasks. Besides, once the physical inventory feature is available, we also plan to add visibility into physical inventory postings that haven't synchronized between systems.

Further Information

SAP Logistics Management Product Page 

SAP Logistics Management What's New Viewer

entry.title: Re: Project Budget Report Is not Working Properly
entry.content:
Hi Arun_Sharma25,

In general, it's difficult to answer those questions without more details or looking at the system.

However, you might check the following:

1.) You must activate the non-default scope item 2I3 (Predictive Commitments Management) in order to enable the budget check function for Commitments. This is a prerequisite for purchase orders and purchase requisitions to generate the commitment value.

You might check with the following app Display Line Items in General Ledger (F2217)  if you find commitment entries on ledger 0E with a future posting date (and Journal Entry starting with PA*).

2.) Have you uploaded enough budget for the respective WBS/accounts?

Regarding the "doubled-amount", I have no answer without looking on the single line items. Thus, in case the issues still exists, please open an incident.

 

Best Regards,

Marcel
